user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of completed_callback:
```c
static void
completed_callback (void *cls,
                    struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                    void **req_cls,
                    enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode toe)
{
  struct timeval *tv = *req_cls;
  struct timeval tve;
  uint64_t delta;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) toe;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (NULL == tv)
    return;
  gettimeofday (&tve, NULL);

  delta = ((uint64_t) (tve.tv_sec - tv->tv_sec)) * 1000000LL
          + (uint64_t) tve.tv_usec - (uint64_t) tv->tv_usec;
  if (delta < SMALL)
    small_deltas[delta]++;
  else
    fprintf (stdout, "D: %" PRIu64 " 1\n", delta);
  free (tv);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function completed_callback:
#define SMALL (1024*128)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (delta < SMALL)
    small_deltas[delta]++;
  else
    fprintf (stdout, "D: %" PRIu64 " 1\n", delta);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. Both branches of the if/else are reachable at run time depending on the computed value of delta (e.g. delta == 0 executes small_deltas[delta]++; delta == SMALL executes the fprintf). Given SMALL is defined as 1024*128 (nonzero), there is no constant expression making one branch permanently unreachable, so MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is not violated here.
